sections.content: The goal of this document or tool is to provide you with general information regarding treatment with a fixed dental prosthesis. Your dentist will be able to identify the specific benefits, risks, and/or alternative treatment options that apply to you
sections.audioText: The goal of this document or tool is to provide you with general information regarding treatment with a fixed dental prosthesis. Your dentist will be able to identify the specific benefits, risks, and/or alternative treatment options that apply to you

sections.section: What is a fixed dental prosthesis?
sections.content: It is a dental treatment that uses artificial replicas to replace part of a tooth or a missing tooth and it is attached permanently to the occurring tooth or teeth.
sections.audioText: It is a dental treatment that uses artificial replicas to replace part of a tooth or a missing tooth and it is attached permanently to the occurring tooth or teeth.

sections.section: What is a crown dental crown?
sections.content: A crown is a restoration that covers or caps the tooth, restoring it to its natural size, shape, color, and function.
sections.audioText: A crown is a restoration that covers or caps the tooth, restoring it to its natural size, shape, color, and function.

sections.content: A dental bridge are artificial teeth that replaces a person's missing tooth or teeth and it’s fixed on occurring tooth or teeth.
sections.audioText: A dental bridge are artificial teeth that replaces a person's missing tooth or teeth and it’s fixed on occurring tooth or teeth.

sections.section: Reasons for the treatment with a crown or bridge
sections.content: There are many indications for a crown or bridge, including-
sections.audioText: There are many indications for a crown or bridge, including-

sections.section: Common Reasons for treatment with a crown or bridge
sections.content: To strengthen a tooth for example a root canal-treated tooth, a cracked tooth, or a tooth with large fillings,
sections.audioText: To strengthen a tooth for example a root canal-treated tooth, a cracked tooth, or a tooth with large fillings,

sections.section: Other Reasons for treatment with a crown or bridge
sections.content: To improve appearance, and
sections.audioText: To improve appearance, and

sections.section: Other Reasons for treatment with a crown or bridge
sections.content: To improve function
sections.audioText: To improve function

sections.section: Other Reasons for treatment with a crown or bridge
sections.content: To replace a missing tooth orteeth.
sections.audioText: To replace a missing tooth or teeth.

sections.content: The crown or bridge protects the tooth/teeth from breaking or if the tooth was heavily filled it will prevent further breakdown.
sections.audioText: The crown or bridge protects the tooth/teeth from breaking or if the tooth was heavily filled it will prevent further breakdown.

sections.content: The crown or bridge may improve the way you bite and chew food.
sections.audioText: The crown or bridge may improve the way you bite and chew food.

sections.content: By removing a damaged or decayed tooth, you protect the integrity of your remaining teeth and support better oral hygiene.
sections.audioText: By removing a damaged or decayed tooth, you protect the integrity of your remaining teeth and support better oral hygiene.

sections.content: With the crown or bridge in place, you can eat a wide range of foods except for very hard foods.
sections.audioText: With the crown or bridge in place, you can eat a wide range of foods except for very hard foods.

sections.content: With the crown or bridge in place, you can eat a wide range of foods except for very hard foods.
sections.audioText: With the crown or bridge in place, you can eat a wide range of foods except for very hard foods.

sections.content: A crown can remain functional for a long period but may not last a lifetime.
sections.audioText: A crown can remain functional for a long period but may not last a lifetime.

sections.content: The patient does not have to periodically remove the crown or bridge because it is cemented onto the remaining tooth or teeth
sections.audioText: The patient does not have to periodically remove the crown or bridge because it is cemented onto the remaining tooth or teeth

sections.content: Depending on the particular dental problem, crowns or bridges can have other benefits, such as improving the shape or color of the natural tooth.
sections.audioText: Depending on the particular dental problem, crowns or bridges can have other benefits, such as improving the shape or color of the natural tooth.

sections.content: Risks associated with receiving local anesthesia include; pain, anxiety, and even the resultant numbness of the tongue, and/or facial tissues which is usually temporary. At times there may be swelling, or jaw muscle tenderness.
sections.audioText: Risks associated with receiving local anesthesia include; pain, anxiety, and even the resultant numbness of the tongue, and/or facial tissues which is usually temporary. At times there may be swelling, or jaw muscle tenderness.

sections.content: It is necessary to reduce the existing tooth or teeth to place the crowns and/or bridge. The tooth reduction is irreversible
sections.audioText: It is necessary to reduce the existing tooth or teeth to place the crowns and/or bridge. The tooth reduction is irreversible.

sections.content: The teeth may exhibit mild to severe sensitivity after tooth preparation, if the crowns are to be made for vital teeth This sensitivity may last only for a short time or may last for much longer periods. If it is persistent, notify the dentist.
sections.audioText: The teeth may exhibit mild to severe sensitivity after tooth preparation, if the crowns are to be made for vital teeth This sensitivity may last only for a short time or may last for much longer periods. If it is persistent, notify the dentist.

sections.section: Risk of having to do root canal treatment for abutment teeth
sections.content: If the tooth to be crowned is vital, it may need to be root canal treated. The need for root canal therapy may become apparent during tooth preparation or after a crown or bridge is made when the tooth becomes non-vital.
sections.audioText: If the tooth to be crowned is vital, it may need to be root canal treated. The need for root canal therapy may become apparent during tooth preparation or after a crown or bridge is made when the tooth becomes non-vital.

sections.content: The prepared tooth may be affected by crown procedures; for instance, it may break due to tooth reduction, or become non-vital, then it may need root canal treatment in the future.
sections.audioText: The prepared tooth may be affected by crown procedures; for instance, it may break due to tooth reduction, or become non-vital, then it may need root canal treatment in the future.

sections.content: Your speech may change temporarily after the crown or bridge is cemented until your tongue and lips become used to it.
sections.audioText: Your speech may change temporarily after the crown or bridge is cemented until your tongue and lips become used to it.

sections.content: Immediately after cementation, it is common to feel a little uneasy with the crown or experience some slight changes in your mouth. Usually, this lasts for a short time.
sections.audioText: Immediately after cementation, it is common to feel a little uneasy with the crown or experience some slight changes in your mouth. Usually, this lasts for a short time.

sections.section: Uncomfortable or strange feeling in jaw joints
sections.content: You may feel uncomfortable in the jaw joints. This may occur because of the differences between natural teeth and artificial replacements and is usually adjusted by the dentist. This feeling should only be temporary.
sections.audioText: You may feel uncomfortable in the jaw joints. This may occur because of the differences between natural teeth and artificial replacements and is usually adjusted by the dentist. This feeling should only be temporary.

sections.content: The prepared teeth may develop tooth decay in case of leakage or ill-fitting crown or bridge margins.
sections.audioText: The prepared teeth may develop tooth decay in case of leakage or ill-fitting crown or bridge margins.

sections.content: Sometimes the crown may fail due to leakage, fracture, or fall off.
sections.audioText: Sometimes the crown may fail due to leakage, fracture, or fall off.

sections.content: Possibility of pain during the procedure or painful gums surrounding the prepared teeth for a few days after tooth preparation
sections.audioText: Possibility of pain during the procedure or painful gums surrounding the prepared teeth for a few days after tooth preparation

sections.section: Re-infection in case of root-filled teeth
sections.content: If your tooth is root-filled, there is always the possibility of re-infection of the tooth roots, independent of any crown and/ or bridge work. This may necessitate additional treatment to the root canals of the tooth.
sections.audioText: If your tooth is root-filled, there is always the possibility of re-infection of the tooth roots, independent of any crown and/ or bridge work. This may necessitate additional treatment to the root canals of the tooth.

sections.content: For this treatment, you might need two or three appointments. At the initial visit, the dentist will take the tooth/teeth shade, begin tooth preparations, and thereafter take measurements of the prepared tooth/teeth and its surrounding teeth. Following tooth preparation, a temporary crown or bridge will be made to preserve the prepared tooth while you wait for the permanent crown or bridge. At the next visit when the final crown or bridge is ready, the dentist will remove the temporary crown, try in the final crown or bridge, and then cement it.
sections.audioText: For this treatment, you might need two or three appointments. At the initial visit, the dentist will take the tooth/teeth shade, begin tooth preparations, and thereafter take measurements of the prepared tooth/teeth and its surrounding teeth. Following tooth preparation, a temporary crown or bridge will be made to preserve the prepared tooth while you wait for the permanent crown or bridge. At the next visit when the final crown or bridge is ready, the dentist will remove the temporary crown, try in the final crown or bridge, and then cement it.

sections.content: It is necessary to numb the tooth or teeth during tooth preparation. This is done by the dentist administering local anesthesia using an injection.
sections.audioText: It is necessary to numb the tooth or teeth during tooth preparation. This is done by the dentist administering local anesthesia using an injection.

sections.content: The dentist will take measurements before and after tooth preparation, to help in the design of temporary and final crowns.
sections.audioText: The dentist will take measurements before and after tooth preparation, to help in the design of temporary and final crowns.

sections.content: A portion of the tooth/or teeth will be cut to create space for the crown or bridge using a dental drill.
sections.audioText: A portion of the tooth/or teeth will be cut to create space for the crown or bridge using a dental drill.

sections.content: You should maintain good oral hygiene and have routine dental check-ups following crown placement.
sections.audioText: You should maintain good oral hygiene and have routine dental check-ups following crown placement.

sections.content: A root canal is a dental procedure to remove infected or damaged pulp from inside a tooth. It helps save the tooth and relieve pain.
sections.audioText: A root canal is a dental procedure to remove infected or damaged pulp from inside a tooth. It helps save the tooth and relieve pain.

sections.section: Why you need a Root Canal
sections.content: You may need a root canal due to severe decay, repeated dental procedures, or trauma that causes pulp damage.
sections.audioText: You may need a root canal due to severe decay, repeated dental procedures, or trauma that causes pulp damage.

sections.content: A root canal allows you to keep your natural tooth, which is essential for chewing and maintaining proper alignment of your other teeth.
sections.audioText: A root canal allows you to keep your natural tooth, which is essential for chewing and maintaining proper alignment of your other teeth.

sections.content: The procedure removes the infected or damaged pulp, providing relief from the pain and discomfort associated with pulp damage.
sections.audioText: The procedure removes the infected or damaged pulp, providing relief from the pain and discomfort associated with pulp damage.

sections.content: Sometimes, not all infected tissue is removed, which could lead to persistent or recurring infection.
sections.audioText: Sometimes, not all infected tissue is removed, which could lead to persistent or recurring infection.

sections.content: There is a small risk that the procedure could damage neighboring teeth or structures in the mouth.
sections.audioText: There is a small risk that the procedure could damage neighboring teeth or structures in the mouth.

sections.content: Your dentist will examine your tooth using X-rays and determine if a root canal is necessary.
sections.audioText: Your dentist will examine your tooth using X-rays and determine if a root canal is necessary.

sections.content: The dentist will make an opening in the tooth to access and remove the infected pulp.
sections.audioText: The dentist will make an opening in the tooth to access and remove the infected pulp.

sections.content: After cleaning the root canals, they are filled with a special material and sealed to prevent future infection.
sections.audioText: After cleaning the root canals, they are filled with a special material and sealed to prevent future infection.

sections.content: A crown or filling is placed on the tooth to restore its function and appearance.
sections.audioText: A crown or filling is placed on the tooth to restore its function and appearance.

sections.content: The procedure involves removing the pulp, cleaning the inside of the tooth, and sealing it. The tooth is then restored with a crown.
sections.audioText: The procedure involves removing the pulp, cleaning the inside of the tooth, and sealing it. The tooth is then restored with a crown.
